facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 206 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 206 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 9, 1951,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated March 9, 1951, of the Orissa High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 9, 1951, of the Orissa High Court in- Appeal from Original decree No. 14 of 1946, arising out of the judgment and decree dated January 31, 1946,

facts.text: Orissa High Court affirmed decision of Subordinate Judge of Sambalpur in Title Suit No. 16 of 1944 except modification of damages.

anchor.surface_text: dated March 9, 1951, by which it substantially affirmed the decision of the learned Subordinate Judge of Sambalpur in Title Suit No. 16 of 1944 except for a modification of the decree for damages awarded by the latter.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge of Sambalpur delivered judgment and decree dated January 31, 1946, in Title Suit No. 16 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from Original decree No. 14 of 1946, arising out of the judgment and decree dated January 31, 1946, of the Court of Subordinate Judge at Sambalpur in Title Suit No. 16 of 1944.

facts.text: Three persons Nimai Charan Misra, Lakshminarayan Misra and Baikuntha Pati brought Title Suit No. 16 of 1944 for declaration of title and possession of properties.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts relating to the appeal are susceptible of a-simple and companycise statement. Three persons Nimai Charan Misra, Lakshminarayan Misra and Baikuntha Pati brought a suit for a declaration of their title to and recovery of possession of certain properties details whereof are number necessary for our purpose.

facts.text: Satyananda, the last male owner, died unmarried in 1902-1903.

anchor.surface_text: The last male owner was Satyananda who died unmarried sometime in 1902-1903, and his mother Haripriya succeeded to the estate.

facts.text: Haripriya succeeded to the estate after Satyananda's death and lived till 1942.

anchor.surface_text: and his mother Haripriya succeeded to the estate. She lived till 1942 but in 1916 she had sold a portion of the property to one Indumati, daughter of Dharanidhar Misra  plaintiffs witness number 4

facts.text: Haripriya sold a portion of the property in 1916 to Indumati, daughter of Dharanidhar Misra.

anchor.surface_text: She lived till 1942 but in 1916 she had sold a portion of the property to one Indumati, daughter of Dharanidhar Misra  plaintiffs witness number 4  and some of the reversioners, namely, Natabar and Janardan,

facts.text: Suit No. 31 of 1917 brought by Natabar and Janardan challenging the alienation, decreed on August 31, 1918, as without legal necessity.

anchor.surface_text: who were agnates of Haripriyas husband Lokenath Parichha, brought a suit challenging the alienation. This suit was Suit No. 31 of 1917 in the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge, Sambalpur. The suit was decreed on August 31, 1918, and the alienation was declared to be without legal necessity and number binding on the reversion after the death of Haripriya.

facts.text: Hindu Law of Inheritance Amendment Act II of 1929 passed in 1929, elevating sister's son in Mitakshara succession.

anchor.surface_text: In 1929 was passed the Hindu Law of Inheritance  Amendment  Act  II of 1929  which inter alia gave to a sisters -son a place in the order of Mitakshara succession higher than the agnates before the amending Act a sisters son ranked as a bandhu, but under it he succeeded next after the sister.

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed to be sons of half-sister of Satyananda, thus before agnates.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs-respondents claimed on the strength of the pedigree which they set up that they were sons of the half-sister of Satyanand and therefore came before the agnates.

facts.text: Defendants, including appellant, contested pedigree, claiming Ahalya and Malabati were daughters of Baidyanath Misra, father of Haripriya.

anchor.surface_text: The companytesting defendants challenged the companyrectness of the pedigree alleged by the plaintiffs- respondents and their main case was that Ahalya and Malabati were -not the daughters of Lokenath Parichha but were daughters of Baidyanath Misra, father of Haripriya.

facts.text: Essential controversy: whether plaintiffs are sons of daughters of Lokenath Parichha by first wife Satyabhama.

anchor.surface_text: As the High Court has put it, the essential companytroversy between the parties centred round the question if the plaintiffs-respondents were the sons of the daughters of Lokenath Parichha by his first wife Satyabhama.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held plaintiffs were sons of daughters of Lokenath and decreed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of that evidence the learned Subordinate Judge held that they were the sons of the daughters of Lokenath Parichha and on that finding the suit was decreed.

facts.text: High Court affirmed Subordinate Judge's finding.

anchor.surface_text: There was an appeal to the High Court, and it affirmed the finding Of the learned Subordinate Judge.

facts.text: Ex. 1 is a petition dated November 2, 1917, filed by Satyabadi on behalf of himself and brothers Baikunth Pati and Dasarath Pati in Suit No. 31 of 1917, containing pedigree.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court relied on Ex. 1, a petition dated November 2, 1917, which Satyabadi on his own behalf and on behalf of his brothers Baikunth Pati and Dasarath Pati had filed in Suit No. 31 of 1917 this petition companytained a pedigree which showed that Ahalya, Brindabati, and Malabati were daughters of Lokenath Parichha by his first wife and Satyabadi, Baikunth and Dasarath were the sons of Ahalya.

facts.text: High Court held Ex. 1 admissible under s. 32(5) Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: The admissi- bility of this document was challenged on behalf of the appellant, but the learned Judges of the High Court held that the document was admissible under s. 32 5  of the Evidence Act.

facts.text: Oral evidence of Janardan Misra (PW2), Sushila Misrani (PW3), Dharanidhar Misra (PW4) relied upon by High Court under s.50 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: As to the oral evidence, Narasimham, J., held that the testimony given by three of the witnesses of the plaintiffs- respondents, namely, Janardan Misra  plaintiffs witness number 2 , Sushila Misrain  plaintiffs witness number 3  and Dharanidhar Misra  plaintiffs witness number 4 was admissible under s. 50 of the Evidence Act,

facts.text: Supreme Court held evidence of Janardan Misra and Dharanidhar Misra admissible under s.50.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the view that the evidence of both Janardan Misra and Dharanidhar Misra was admissible under s. 50 and the learned Judges of the High Court companymitted numbererror of law in admitting and companysidering that evidence.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Ex.1 admissible under s.32(5) Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we agree with the High Court that Ex. I fulfilled all the companyditions of s. 32 5 , Evidence Act and was admissible in evidence.

facts.text: Janardan Misra aged 62 in 1946, related to Baidyanath Misra's family, attended marriages and ceremonies indicating belief in pedigree.

anchor.surface_text: Janardan Misra was aged about 62 in 1946, and he was related to the family of Baidyanath Misra. Kashi Nath Misra was his grand-father and was a brother of Baidyanath Misra. Obviously, therefore, Janardan Misra had special means of knowing the disputed relationship,

facts.text: Dharanidhar Misra aged 96 in 1946, attended marriages and ceremonies.

anchor.surface_text: The same criteria apply to the evidence of Dharanidhar Misra, who was aged 96 at the time when he gave evidence.

Two questions of law arise in this appeal, one relating to the interpretation of s. 32, sub-s.  5  and the other to S. 50 of the Indian Evidence Act  I of 1872 , hereinafter referred to as the Evidence Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Admissibility of statements by deceased person relating to relationship by blood, marriage or adoption, made with special knowledge before dispute arose

anchor.surface_text: Two questions of law arise in this appeal, one relating to the interpretation of s. 32, sub-s.  5  and the other to S. 50 of the Indian Evidence Act  I of 1872 , hereinafter referred to as the Evidence Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Opinion expressed by conduct as to relationship by person with special means of knowledge

anchor.surface_text: The Evidence Act states that the expression facts in issue means and includes any fact from which either by itself or in connection with other facts the existence, non-existence, nature or extent of any right, liability or disability asserted or denied in any suit or proceeding necessarily follow evidence means and includes (1) all statements which the Court permits or requires to be made before it by witnesses in relation to matters of fact under enquiry, and (2) all documents produced for the inspection of the Court.

concepts.interpretation: Definitions of 'facts in issue', 'evidence', and 'relevant' used to contextualize ss. 50 and 60

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: and may, therefore, be proved. We are of the view that the true scope and effect of section 50 of the Evidence Act has been companyrectly and succinct

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 of the Evidence Act lays down that evidence may be given in any suit or proceeding of the existence or non-existence of every fact in issue and of such other facts as are declared to be relevant and of no others.

concepts.interpretation: Limits evidence to facts in issue and relevant facts, contextualizing relevancy under s.50

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: on. When the companyduct is of such a tenor, the Court only gets to a relevant piece of evidence, namely, the opinion of a person. It still remains fo

concepts.unlisted_description: Evidence restricted to facts in issue and relevant facts

anchor.surface_text: S. 50. When the Court has to form an opinion as to the relationship of one person to another, the opinion, expressed by conduct, as to the existence of such relationship, of any person who, as a member of the family or otherwise, has special means of knowledge on the subject, is a relevant fact

concepts.interpretation: Essential requirements: (1) court forming opinion on relationship; (2) opinion by conduct relevant; (3) person must have special means of knowledge. Opinion means belief manifested in conduct, proved per s.60.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ompanyrt has to form an opinion as to that relationship. Part 11 of the Evidence Act is headed On Proof . Chapter III thereof companytains a fascicule

anchor.surface_text: S. 60. Oral evidence must, in all cases whatever, be direct that is to say- if it refers to a fact which could be seen, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he saw it if it refers to a fact which could be heard, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he heard it if it refers to a fact which could be perceived by any other sense or in any other manner, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he perceived it by that sense in that manner if it refers to an opinion or to the grounds on which that opinion is held, it must be the evidence of the person who holds that opinion on those grounds.

concepts.interpretation: Conduct under s.50 proved as direct oral evidence by witnesses who perceived it; does not require the person whose conduct it is to testify if deceased.

anchor.surface_text: Janardan Misra was aged about 62 in 1946, and he was related to the family of Baidyanath Misra. Kashi Nath Misra was his grand-father and was a brother of Baidyanath Misra. Obviously, therefore, Janardan Misra had special means of knowing the disputed relationship,

holdings.text: Under s.50, conduct expressing opinion on relationship must be proved as direct evidence under s.60 by witnesses who perceived it, not necessarily by the person whose conduct it is.

anchor.surface_text: S. 60. Oral evidence must, in all cases whatever, be direct that is to say- if it refers to a fact which could be seen, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he saw it if it refers to a fact which could be heard, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he heard it

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conduct is external fact provable by any direct witness; s.60 applies to proof of conduct, not requiring the opiner to testify if deceased or unavailable.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellant has referred us to the decision in Subbiah Mudaliar v. Gopala Mudaliar  1  where it was held that for a statement in a former suit to be admissible under s. 32 5  the fact that the person who made the statement had special means of knowledge must be shown by some independent evidence,

precedents.cited_proposition: special means of knowledge for s.32(5) must be shown by independent evidence, not circularly from document itself

anchor.surface_text: In Hitchins v. Eardley  2  the question of the legitimacy of the declarant was in issue and the same question was necessary to be proved in order to admit his declarations. That was a jurv case and the ques- tion relating to the admissibility of evidence being a question of law had to be determined by the Judge

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we agree with the High Court that Ex. I fulfilled all the conditions of s. 32(5), Evidence Act and was admissible in evidence. We have already said that it is not for us to consider what weight should be given to the oral evidence of Janardan and Dharanidhar or to the statements in Ex. 1. The courts below have considered that evidence and have assessed it. We do not think that we shall be justified in going behind that assessment.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; admissibility of evidence under ss. 32(5) and 50 upheld; no interference with lower courts' findings on pedigree and title in favour of plaintiffs-respondents

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the view that the evidence of both Janardan Misra and Dharanidhar Misra was admissible under s. 50 and the learned Judges of the High Court committed no error of law in admitting and considering that evidence.

Therefore, we agree with the High Court that Ex. I fulfilled all the conditions of s. 32(5), Evidence Act and was admissible in evidence. We have already said that it is not for us to consider what weight should be given to the oral evidence of Janardan and Dharanidhar or to the statements in Ex. 1. The courts below have considered that evidence and have assessed it. We do not think that we shall be justified in going behind that assessment.

Janardan Misra was aged about 62 in 1946, and he was related to the family of Baidyanath Misra. Kashi Nath Misra was his grand-father and was a brother of Baidyanath Misra. Obviously, therefore, Janardan Misra had special means of knowing the disputed relationship,
